name: Lanterna History
desc:
This is a complete History of Lanterna. You are very familiar with this book since you have studied it in school. Here are the main events...

-After leaving Charn, Elos led them to this new world. \"Them\" were Derik and Elee Wendur and their four daughters and daughter's husbands.

-They, along with the other races, began to create the city of Charn.

-Elos created the Living Tree in the center of town. This tree would extend the life of a human who partook of its fruit once a year. The average life expectancy was around 250 years.

-The Mountain Dwarves live near by in the mountains and the Wood Elves and Talking Beast spread out over the land. There are many other good races brought here by Elos.

-over 20 years ago, the last of the son of Derik passed away. Zorn the Eldest son of Valdur, wanted to become king of Charn. Since Valdur was the eldest son-in-law of Derik, Zorn felt it was his right to be King. Elos had set up a government of judges, saying that Charn should never have a king if they wanted to keep their freedom.

-The people of Charn rejected Zorn's idea of setting up a monarchy. He and his followers plotted to take over the town, but were discovered and banished forever.

-Since then, people who ventured into the forest would sometimes disappear.

-Your parents were some of those who disappeared. You have since been taking care of your younger sister by working at the docks.

Verto,

I grow tired of being Zorn's messenger and jail keeper. Be prepared, for the battle begins ere long.

Volt

name: ABCs of Geography
desc:
ABCs of Geography:
A Geography of Abeir-Toril in Bad Rhyme
by Hoblin Meeter

A is for Amn, of merchants and gold.
Baldur's Gate gives us B, the Sword Coast's stronghold.
C is for Calimshan, empire of sand.
D is for Daggerdale, among the Dalelands.
E is Evereska, haven of Elves.
F is for Faerun, where most of us dwell.
G is for the Great Dale, lonely and far.
H is Halruaa, of magic bizarre.
Icewind Dale gives us I, cold and remote.
But J is for jungle, the Jungles of Chult.
K's for Kara-Tur, of spices and silk.
L is for Luiren, where live halfling ilk.
M is for Moonsea, cold, clear, and perilous.
N is for Narfell, at least if you're querulous.
O is for Ordulin, Sembia's chief city.
P is for Phlan, thrice-built and gritty.
Q is for Quaervarr, which nobody knows.
R is Ravens Bluff, of many past woes.
S is for Scornubel, caravan town.
T is for Tethyr, and the Queen-Monarch's crown.
U is for Unther, fallen from glory.
V is for the Vast, of legend and story.
W is for Waterdeep, of cities supreme.
X is excessive in this simple scheme.
Y is  for Yuirwood, where dwell the half-elves.
Z is for Zhentil, may it sink to the Hells!

name: Brother Anselm's Journal
desc: The two men that the church of Asbravn sends me have arrived. Dunne and Obern are their names--it's strange; I do not recognize them, and Asbravn is quite small. They are civil enough, and their devotion to Ilmater seems sincere, if somewhat--how shall I put it?--too scrupulous. But ah! I fear that my own doubts have begun to influence how I perceive others... ...Oh, with what strange trials does Ilmater test us! Having long feared the influence of the Risen Sun cult in this region, I wrote to my church in Asbravn one fortnight hence to inquire whether the self-proclaimed "servants of Amaunator" had made any headway there. The answer has shaken me to my core. It came today, and was written by old Philippus--the pillar of our church, the one who introduced me to the worship of the Crying God! He and the other Ilmatari of Asbravn have converted to the beliefs of the Risen Sun. He wishes me to write to Theophilus, the priest of Amaunator now preaching in Corm Orp; he claims that Theophilus showed him light where there was darkness, healing where there was only suffering before; he claims that I, too, should worship Amaunator as the one true god. Ilmater save me!... ...The body of the poor traveler killed by bandits was interred today in the crypt, his brother and an adventurer the only ones to see him at rest. How can such evil things happen in the world, if Amaunator, as Theophilus has claimed to me in one of his letters, is the true god & the source of all good? "There is no evil, Anselm, there is only misunderstanding." So says Theophilus. "Walk in Love." ...Theophilus writes again. The Flame Stone near town, the site thought to be sacred to Sune, is a place that is truly holy only to Amaunator. He says, "He is the only god of Love!" ...It must have been Ilmater who compelled me to reveal to the adventurers a day or two hence my "fears" about the Risen Sun. If so, that was his last act of intervention, the last imposition of darkness on a soul now illuminated: My heart, I feel, belongs to Amaunator! Theophilus is a convincing writer; what must it be to hear him preach?! I hope that I shall have the opportunity one day to allay whatever doubts I have left. I must speak with Hamfast soon; I can no longer serve Drawn Swords, or Ilmater, in good faith...

name: Poems of Clairey Johns
desc:
POEMS OF CLAIREY JOHNS

A rustic poet raised in Deadsnows, a village in the Silver Marches, Clairey Johns died in 1360 DR, content to have lived a life among her native people and never to have felt the call of the city that so many poets feel.  This book collects her greatest efforts, and includes many which she wrote in the voice of a male persona, including "I was a boy without a home":

I was a boy without a home,
I slept among the heather.
On many roads my boots did roam
In many kinds of weather.

When autumn came I met a lass
And sweet it was to hear her;
In wintertime the river-glass
I fashioned for her mirror.

She loved it well, among the snows,
But then in spring it melted--
And so I made her floral clothes,
Bloom-spun and willow-belted.

She loved these too, and summer came;
I made that lass a mother.
But ere the babe, the autumn came;
I left her for another.

name: Oussonian's Ballads
desc:
OUSSONIAN'S BALLADS

Oussonian was among the greatest of the elven troubadours, and one of the only ones to write verse in both elven and common--a characteristic many scholars attribute to his having lived in the Age of Alliance, that time between the Dales Compact and the days of Myth Drannor's glory (and subsequent fall).  One of his most famous poems in the common tongue is this ballad, addressed to the conventional "Belle Dame Sans Merci":

"I find a cup among the ferns,
I drain it to the leas;
The wine inside both cools and burns,
Oh belle dame sans merci!"

"I give it you to keep you young,"
She laughing says to me;
"The cup of life, it over-runs,
Oh belle dame sans merci!"

"Then why not sleep the liquor off,
Among these ferns so green?"
"Then on thy breast, both cruel and soft,
I'll sleep, dame sans merci."

And now I lie among the ferns,
Far from road and sea.
The sun and moon look down by turns,
But neither pities me.

name: Of Magical Guardians
desc: Of Magical Guardians: The Golem and Its Uses An Account by Normis Teluvar, Archmage of Tilverton At least since the age of Netheril, the magical guardian par excellence has been the golem. Interestingly, human mages have always employed golems more frequently than the elves, perhaps because the elven wizard has always been a part of mainstream elven society, and elven magic has therefore aimed at more universal applications of protective magic--i.e., the mythal. It is, however, quite common for the elves to bury their dead with golems and summoned elementals... This book encapsulates my research on the many permutations of the golem over time, posits some of the basic differences between golem sentience and animal sentience, and discusses some relatively untried potentials for golems in industry and manufacture. But first, an overview of the basic qualities of the golem may be useful for the student... Golems, though they can vary greatly, do have some characteristics in common: The golem is highly resistant to normal weapons, for instance, but weapons made of the rare mineral adamant bypass this resistance, to a degree. Some golems, such as the clay golem--which is resistant to sword and dagger, but vulnerable to the heavy blows of a mace or hammer--have additional resistance to certain weapon types... Here, then, is a short list of golem types. It is hardly comprehensive, as every golem is, in a sense, a unique creature, and may vary according to the whim of his maker. But here, nonetheless, are the some of the recorded types: flesh, clay, stone, and iron golems are by far the most common; but there are also brass, chain, dragonflesh, glass, alchemical, hangman, gloom, shadesteel, prismatic, mud, fang, blood, brain, ice, sand, coral, mithral, and demonflesh golems...

name: The Fall of Northkeep
desc: The Fall of Northkeep An Account by Gorion of Candlekeep The wild lands of Thar were once home to the orcs and ogres of what was called by men the Black Allilance, and Northkeep, the first true human city in the Moonsea region, would be the first of many to fall to their numbers. Indeed, the city, mighty as it might have become, lasted only fifty-two years, having been erected in 348 DR and falling in 400 DR, the Year of the Blue Shield... Among the leaders of the Black Alliance was Vorbyx, First King of Thar, who wielded a great hammer as he led his humanoid army against the city. The true nature of this personage is lost to a host of fabulous myths regarding him... The city was sunk beneath the Moonsea, then called the Dragon Sea. The exact cause of this dramatic finish has never been agreed upon by scholars, but many theories posit that, having been weakened by the military might of the Black Alliance, the shamans of the humanoid tribes brought it about through a massive ritual invoking half the evil pantheon they worshipped. In any case, the destruction of Northkeep, final as it was, was ironically the last truly concerted effort on the part of the tribes of Thar. They brought many other cities low, but never again in such numbers or with such unity of effort.

name: Chardalyns
desc:
CHARDALYNS
A Small Mystery among the Many Great Mysteries of Netheril
Hamask Atyri, in the name of Azuth

Few wizards know the term "chardalyn," though magician-scholars steeped in Netherese lore have surely come across the word.  It refers to a small, nondescript gem mined by accident at a site near the Zweihaus River and Wont Surge--two bodies of water long since evaporated among the dusts of Anauroch--at the beginning of the Second Millennium (NY)....  

Requiring no extra enchantment, these remarkable stones could be imbued with spells that would function fully on their destruction; for years Netherese arcanists desperately sought how to employ them for some practical magical purpose, but failed, as the stones were too fragile to be used in any kind of mechanical way without danger....

We have no reason to doubt the Netherese lore on these stones, as it has proven so trustworthy in all other areas of magical study.  What, then, should a theorist of magic make of them?  Are they crystallizations of the Weave?  But then, I would ask, why do they not have any magical properties of their own?  I theorize that they are placeholders of pre-Weave, primordial existence, crystallizations of creation itself, ripe for the Weave, but not yet parts of it.  Alas, that they are all lost!

name: The Faerunian Pantheon, Book I
desc: THE FAERUNIAN PANTHEON Being a brief Survey of the Major Deities Worshipped by Men on this Continent Book the First: Of Oghma my Patron, and, Following, the Deities of Nature By Namer Ollivarus of Procampur, Year of the Horn (1222 DR) I begin with Oghma, my patron and the Lord of Knowledge, whose church is based here, in mighty Procampur of the Vast. He is the deity most concerned with the preservation of knowledge in all its forms, and his servants are manifold and diverse--from travel-weary bards, to custodians of the great libraries, to the solitary clerics who work through all their waking hours at the supreme task of collating and copying works of erudition.... Of the most commonly worshipped beings in Faerun, Chauntea is probably the oldest, for she is the goddess of agriculture and fertility, and for this reason has her origins in prehistory, when men first planted seeds and harvested crops, but had not yet put pen to paper....She is worshipped by common folk especially, and particularly those who depend on the fields for their livelihood.... Like Chauntea, Silvanus the Oak Father is incredibly old and widely worshipped, though his followers are more reclusive than the Earthmother's; indeed, he counts druids among them, and may have more druidic followers than he has traditional clerics. His most strident adherents sabotage the encroachment of civilization onto pristine woodlands, the place most sacred to their god and the high seat of the "Balance" they see as integral to existence itself.... Mielikki is a young goddess, daughter of Silvanus, and is called the Lady of the Forest. She is gentler than her father; and if he is the god of the deep forest, of mighty pines and oaks, of the simple and sometimes cruel cycle of hunter and hunted, then she is the goddess of the glades, the sun-dappled maple and blueleaf, the unicorn and deer. Mielikki is especially popular among those who would balance the needs of civilization with the needs of the forest....

name: The Faerunian Pantheon, Book II
desc: THE FAERUNIAN PANTHEON Being a brief Survey of the Major Deities Worshipped by Men on this Continent Book the Second: Of the Deities of Fury By Namer Ollivarus of Procampur, Year of the Horn (1222 DR) Chief of the so-called Deities of Fury is Talos the Destroyer, an ancient god whom theologians trace to the primordial battle between Selune and Shar; his cult was first founded on the fear of nature, rather than reverence for it, and to this day he is the god of natural disaster and chance destruction, and particularly of lightning. The antiquity of Talos can be perceived in the multitude of names for him, some extremely old, that persist among certain peoples--Bhaelros in the south, and Kozah among the Bedine of Anauroch.... Malar, too, is ancient, but his portfolio consists of the feral beasts, the savage hunt, and bloodlust; if Talos owns the fury of the inorganic, Malar owns the fury of the organic. Malar is called the Beastlord, and it is likely that worship of him derived from prehistoric hunting rituals. Those who have witnessed a rite of Malar wonder whether the blessings of civilization and the beauty of knowledge are all a strange dream, and fear that we shall some day awake to find ourselves brutes.... Umberlee rules the waves, and is called the Bitch Queen by sailors, among whom she counts the greatest part of her worshippers, who worship her out of fear rather than love. She is vain and cruel, and jealous of Talos, who can wreak havoc over sea and land, while she is confined to the sea....

name: The Faerunian Pantheon, Book III
desc: THE FAERUNIAN PANTHEON Being a brief Survey of the Major Deities Worshipped by Men on this Continent Book the Third: Of Selune, Shar, and Mystra By Namer Ollivarus of Procampur, Year of the Horn (1222 DR) Faerunian creation myths posit that Selune, as primordial divinity of light, lit the orb of the sun and angered her sister Shar, divinity of the darkness; the ensuing battle gave birth to Mystryl, later Mystra, the Mother of All Magic. It is a tale that most children know. The present work will examine the modern worship of these three goddesses.... Selune the Moonmaiden is servitor of Sune Firehair, though her role in ancient times was greater; indeed, some predict that her worship will increase again. As goddess of the moon and tides, she is worshipped primarily among travelers, and those seafarers bold enough to discount the wrath of Umberlee. More abstractly, she is sometimes worshipped as the goddess of mutability and process. Accordingly, there is no established structure for the Selunite church. Shar, the Lady of Loss, is worshipped secretly, as most civilizations despise her cult and its principles....Goddess of darkness, Shar is also goddess of nihilism. As such, she is a paradoxical being, hating and loving herself simultaneously, seeking both to accrue more power and to undo herself and all of existence.... Mystra is at once goddess of magic and magic itself, being the embodiment of the Weave, the cosmic structure by which the primordial energy can be tapped....Mystrya's church is one of the most powerful on Faerun, which is no surprise, considering the stakes of magical practice here.

name: The Faerunian Pantheon, Book IV
desc: THE FAERUNIAN PANTHEON Being a brief Survey of the Major Deities Worshipped by Men on this Continent Book the Fourth: Of the Gods of War By Namer Ollivarus of Procampur, Year of the Horn (1222 DR) There are many gods of war, almost as many as there are armies pitted against each other. Of these deities, though, three will be the subject of this survey--Tempus, Uthgar, and Helm, the last being included here for the military hierarchy of his church and his role as defender par excellence.... Tempus is also known as the Lord of Battles, Foehammer, and, among the barbarians of the North, Tempos. The church of the god of war is the most popular in Faerun, for he claims adherents among the rich and the poor, the civilized and the uncivilized, the good and the evil; in war, his clerics claim, all things are equal except for individual prowess; without conflict, there would never be resolution.... Uthgar is a primitive divinity, and is worshipped only among the barbarians. It is worth considering his particular dogma in the light of Tempus's as evidence of the former god's superiority in terms of universal, cross-cultural appeal.... Uthgar disparages arcane magic, promotes the veneration of tribal beast totems, and encourages manly strength and prejudice at the expense of cosmopolitanism and literacy. Despite these narrow restrictions, the centuries-old barbarian tribes still fight in his name; the very severity of his cult empowers his worshippers with a sense of fanatical zeal. Without such a culturally embedded religion, the barbarians would undoubtedly submit to the lures of civilization. Helm is the Watcher or the Vigilant One, the patron of defenders and defensive warfare. His temples are often like fortresses, and, in savage lands, act as bastions of civilization, but the strict hierarchy of his clergy, even as it establishes his church's military power, undermines its appeal to the masses....Ironically, corruption is all too common in the church....

name: The Faerunian Pantheon, Book V
desc: THE FAERUNIAN PANTHEON Being a brief Survey of the Major Deities Worshipped by Men on this Continent Book the Fifth: Of the Gods of Civilization By Namer Ollivarus of Procampur, Year of the Horn (1222 DR) Gond is the god of technology and invention. He is the servant of my patron Oghma. He is also the god of crafting, and the human god of the forge; in places he is worshipped merely in that capacity, his greater virtues being elided by the clergy in their desire to attract worshippers among craftsmen and commoners.... Waukeen is called the Merchant's Friend, and is particularly popular among the aggressive trading nations of Sembia, Amn, and Calimshan. She is goddess of commerce and wealth, and her followers are mostly merchants; pure-blooded aristocrats, on the other hand, are ambivalent toward her church, which they see as somewhat crass and obvious, and tend to follow Lathander or whatever god is most traditional among their people.... Lathander is, in one respect, a truly ancient god, having his origin among the solar cults of aboriginal peoples, and ought not to be classified with the deities of civilization; at the same time, he and his church have constantly reinvented themselves, and, wherever civilization has flourished, so has his cult. Some argue that Lathander is, in fact, the most recent incarnation of an old sun god called Amaunator. As god of renewal, the belief, at least, is justified. The worship of Sune, goddess of love and beauty, is most prevalent in those places where the pen is mighter than the sword, the economy healthy, and the people comely. Even in such places, her followers are sometimes criticized for being effete or foolish. Those who make such accusations, though, do so at their own peril, for Sune is quick to punish skeptics with a healthy dose of unrequited love.

name: The Faerunian Pantheon, Book VI
desc: THE FAERUNIAN PANTHEON Being a brief Survey of the Major Deities Worshipped by Men on this Continent Book the Sixth: Of the Triad By Namer Ollivarus of Procampur, Year of the Horn (1222 DR) The deities of the Triad (sometimes called the Holy Triad and, among rural peoples, the Trefoil) are Ilmater, Torm, and Tyr.... Ilmater is called both the Crying and the Broken God, and he gives comfort to all those who suffer. Many of his worshippers are the meek, the oppressed, and the lame--in short, all those whom abuse of power has brought low; but he is also worshipped by the strong of heart, who love him for teaching them humility and the lessons of suffering. Numerous ascetic cults in the name of Ilmater have come and gone, many of them fanatical and heretical, according to the pronouncements of the official church.... Tyr is chief of the Triad, and is called the Just God, for law and justice is his province. He loves institution, truth, and order, and his church tries to emulate him in their pursuit of these things. Order in harmony with goodness, Tyrrans claim, is the bedrock of existence itself.... If Tyr smiles on the dutiful, Torm, his servant, also called the Loyal Fury, embodies duty itself. He is admired especially by conservative peoples, in lands where a benign old aristocratic or feudal order prevails; he is also worshipped by warriors, for his swordarm is quick, and he always strikes true.

name: The Faerunian Pantheon, Book VII
desc: THE FAERUNIAN PANTHEON Being a brief Survey of the Major Deities Worshipped by Men on this Continent Book the Seventh: Of the Dark Three By Namer Ollivarus of Procampur, Year of the Horn (1222 DR) Bane is chief among the gods of evil, for he is supreme tyrant, and is called the Lord of Darkness even by those who hate him. His law is unconditional service to him alone, a service which demands fearful obedience and acts of reprehensible villainy. His church is based in Zhentil Keep.... Myrkul is the god of death, a cruel and selfish being, lord of necromancers and those who hate life. The worship of death as a being is an ancient practice, but Myrkul's cult is more recent and less benevolent than most death cults, which tend to view death as a stage of transition, rather than the goal of existence. Copyist's note: Myrkul is, of course, now dead. Kelemvor is the present god of death, and is a much more benign figure than Myrkul.... Bhaal is Lord of Murder, the deity of senseless bloodshed, mayhem, and cruel assassination. He is as wicked as Bane, but has no visions of worldwide tyranny, only worldwide slaughter....Copyist's note: Bhaal, too, is now dead. Cyric, Prince of Lies, has assumed his portfolio....

name: Gossam's Cape
desc: A simple cape of green--not particularly warm but useful, perhaps, for hiding oneself in the wild.  Such garments are common among halfings, who dislike heavy clothing.  A minor spell of illusion has been incorporated into this particular garment.

name: Harp & Chrysanthemum Journal
desc: This is the journal from the time you spent in Drawn Swords and the Backlands. It contains the record of your adventures there, preserved for posterity. [In non-game terms, this item saves valuable information from Harp & Chrysanthemum for future use. Do not lose it!]

name: Ianth's Armor
desc: A highly ornamental but still functional suit of chainmail, commissioned by Ianth Lavillus when she was inducted into the Order of the Ruby Rose.  Portions of it are inlaid with deep crimson bloodstone, crimson being a favorite color of Sune, goddess of love.

name: Chain Sunite Armor
desc: A highly ornamental but still functional suit of chainmail, commissioned by Ianth Lavillus when she was inducted into the Order of the Ruby Rose.  Portions of it are inlaid with deep crimson bloodstone, crimson being a favorite color of Sune, goddess of love.

name: Ianth's Traveling Cloak
desc: A deep red cloak, heavy enough to withstand the coldest breezes of autumn.  The dye's brilliance and the intricate needlework at the hem suggest that this garment was expertly and expensively tailored.

name: Lessons to Children
desc:
LESSONS TO CHILDREN
by Aglasz Jhavildar, "Sage of Teziir"
Vol. 1
1.  Listen to thy parents and speak well of them to others.
2.  Respect thy teachers, and especially Dames Experience, Wisdom, and Virtue.
3.  Learn to read and to sing.
4.  Despise the sword thou carriest.
5. Kindness to animals and strangers.
5. Pray to the gods of virtue, and despise the gods of vice.
6.  Walk often; swimming, jumping, and riding provoke violence.
7.  Eat more of the fruits of the harvest than of the flesh of the field.
8. Coin is the wise man's magic.
9.  Refuse leniency.
10.  Serve thy city every day.

name: Sunite Shield
desc: This is an enchanted version of the standard shield borne by paladins of the Order of the Ruby Rose, a group of knights who honor Sune, and particularly the Sunite doctrine "Love conquers all."  This motto is engraved in Espruar runes on the back of the shield.  Ianth received it from the Order before she set off on her pilgrimage to the Flame Stone, the sacred site near Drawn Swords.

name: Berduskan Honey-White
desc: Fermented near Berdusk, this gentle, rather floral white wine remains a standard in high-class establishments throughout northern Faerun.

name: Yellow Rose Blueberry Wine
desc: Brewed from blueberries and a secret herbal tincture by monks at the Yellow Rose Monastery of Ilmater, this beloved, deep purple wine is known to promote good cheer, and is especially popular with halflings and gnomes.

name: Elventree Ruby-Red
desc: A dark, satisfying wine that has a bouquet vaguely reminiscent of rain-washed woods.

name: Eye of Mulhorand Beer
desc: An excellent and popular brew common throughout central and southern Faerun.

name: Rashemi Firewine
desc: This is a diluted version of Rashemen's jealously guarded national liquor, but still packs a fiery punch.

name: Keepers' Cordial
desc: This herbal liqueur has been brewed by the Oghmanyte monks of Candlekeep for centuries.  It is a light, almost yellow green, and tastes strongly of anise, wormwood, and almond flowers.

name: Mistledale Bubbling Ale
desc: Mistledale Bubbling Ale is a distinctively effervescent, hearty brew from the Dalelands.

name: Moonshavian Whiskey
desc: This deceptively smooth whiskey is said to be the true force behind today's peace between the Northlanders and Ffolk of the Moonshae Isles.

name: Scardale Lager
desc: A smooth, rich lager from Scardale, with an aroma of an autumn meadow.

name: Stojanow Ale
desc: A watery, cheap, but effective brew from Phlan.

name: Vilhon Cherry-Red
desc: This wine, from the famous vineyards of the Vilhon Reach, is especially fruity and buoyant.

name: Vilhon Reach Champagne
desc: Champagne is a rarity in the Realms, and the only true champagne grape grows in a well-guarded vineyard in the Vilhon Reach.  Bubbly, golden, and elegant, this bottle is a real treasure.

name: Flask of Acid
desc: Flasks of highly potent acids, such as this one, are often used by alchemists in their trade.  Acid also has a number of medical and even artistic uses, though adventurers prize it mostly for its capabilities against regenerating creatures.

name: Costume Amaunatori Armor (Cleric)
desc: enter item's description here

name: Amaunauth Poison
desc: This unusual poison has been extracted from amaunauth or "greenflower," a plant whose bright green sepals (its petals are dull and yellow) give it its common name.  It is highly toxic to humans, elves, orcs, and goblinoids, but is harmless to other creatures.

name: Aniphilistes' Scythe
desc: Aniphilistes, Keeper of the Secret Hoard, member of the Dragonwell Cell of the Cult of the Dragon, and the creator and most recent possessor of this weapon, was a man of maniacal genius and a flair for the dramatic. His involvement in the Cult of the Dragon was fanatical but also heretical: he thought it possible to transform himself into a dragon, and then into a dracolich; and, interpreting Sammaster's prophecies piecemeal, thence into supreme ruler of Faerun. None of this was to be, of course--even had he lived. But this cruel scythe kept him alive long enough to make him believe that his dreams were coming true.

name: Heart of the Armanite
desc: This large, blackened heart--of a horse-bodied demon known as an armanite--still beats and throbs on occasion, though Gargothis explained that this is a result of the magic that binds the heart to the Prime Material Plane, and not of some insidious, abiding life force of the heart's original possessor.  The fact that the heart still exists at all is something of a miracle, given the penchant of a demon's body parts to evaporate or to ooze away once it has been slain.  Its powers replicate, in a small part, a measure of the armanite's dreadful capacity as one of the most insatiable and skilled combatants of the Plains of Gallenshu, the 337th layer of the Abyss; unfortunately its disturbing presence has a tendency to sap the will of its bearer.

name: Powder of Reluvethel's Aster
desc: This astonishing powder was prepared by Gossam Thistlefall out of the exceedingly rare and magical golden aster named after the elven ranger Reluvethel.  When thrown, the powder attracts a creature to fight on behalf of the powder's owner.

name: Amulet of Namer Auvyrion
desc: Namer Auvyrion was the head cleric of Oghma in Saerloon, a job which had its share of headaches while the young nation of Sembia negotiated peace with the elves.  In 886 DR, the Year of the Fell Firebreak, the soaring gothic library and temple of Oghma in Saerloon was chosen as neutral ground for what turned out to be a fiery debate between the diplomats of Cormanthor and Sembia.  While it raged, Namer Auvyrion, who had been chosen to mediate, is said to have repeatedly clutched the tiny silver globe of this amulet.  "It helps me keep a level head," he explained to an inquisitive elf.  Little did the elf know how true this statement was.

name: Beluiren Weizenbier
desc: This wheat beer has a truly extraordinary taste, somehow both floral and hearty.  It is light in color--almost like white gold--and easy to drink, but still an extremely heady brew.  Only the halflings of Luiren know the secrets behind this delicious concoction.

name: Black Heart Circlet
desc: This circlet was worn by Destevedh ("the Black Heart") of Suldstev, sorcerer-king of a little-known warrior clan that lived on the borders of ancient Netheril.  In -2488 DR, the Suldstevans allied with a horde of orcs who wished to check Netheril's conquest of the south.  Ioulaum, the famous archwizard of Netheril, led an assault against the gathered forces.  Destevedh, who was more feared than loved by his people, was buried with this circlet and all but forgotten.

name: Bloodstaunch
desc: A sprig of bloodstaunch, a low-growing herb found in the Backlands and other wild areas of Faerun, can temporarily thicken the blood of the individual who uses it.

name: Black Monitor's Skullcap
desc: The city of Skuld, in Mulhorand, is the oldest continually inhabited city of men in Faerun, and it shows in the interesting contrasts it offers the perceptive.  Labyrinthine, crumbling alleyways abut sun-baked plazas, full of gossip and commodities; ancient palaces loom over the humbler buildings of the decaying empire; and, in the dark cellars beneath the City of the Gods--the district where the Mulhorandi deities have their temples--the Black Cult of Ahm, a semi-secret organization dedicated to acquiring demonic lore, continues its esoteric pursuit, even as the dutiful citizens above go to temple.  How this skullcap, once in the possession of Skuld's Black Monitor (a high rank in the cult), was permitted to leave Mulhorand in the hands of a mere disciple is a mystery that no common effort of perception--or even divination--can penetrate.

name: Boar's Blood
desc: Gossam has refined the tiny petals and sepals of the boar's blood plant into a magical poultice and stowed it in this pouch.  When a bit is applied to an open wound, the target creature is slowly healed.  The poultice looks like it could be used once per day over the course of a tenday.

name: Eben's Bane
desc: Unlike similarly named weapons that denote exceptional prowess against a particular foe, the "Bane" in this weapon's name refers to its unique power--the ability to strike enemies with a temporary divine curse upon each successful blow.  "Eben" is simply the name of its original owner, Eben Hakston.  The nobleman of Iriaebor had been so pleased with a suit of half-plate with similar powers, that he commissioned this sword in the belief that, together with the armor, it would make all of his enemies weaken and quail before him.

name: Bruyken's Boast
desc: This lute belonged to a courtier, poet, and adventurer of the Ffolk of the Moonshaes named Emrbyn Bruyken--a man infamous for boasting, but famous for his talents.  One day at court, he boasted that a traveler from the mainland had indicated for him the location of Castle Joyous, the setting of the anonymous poem "The Falcon and the Dove."  If this was so, his friends told him, he ought to find the castle himself and bring back some proof of his visit.  Unfortunately, he found the castle, but lost his life; his lute is all that survives of his tale.  The instrument's magic is quite curious: a bard who has the lute in his possession has the ability to impress and bluff his audience--whether or not he is actually playing or even holding it.

name: Cap of the Wanton Namer
desc: This wine-colored, velvet cap was tailored by a gnomish runecaster and devotee of Oghma who often used it to aid his amorous adventures.  Using it, he found that he could charm a would-be quarry without actually drawing attention to the fact that he was using magic.  The trick failed when he tried it on a canny assassin, who suspected the nature of the cap.  She pretended to be enchanted; followed him to his home; slit his throat; and took the cap and everything else he owned.  The clerics of Oghma use this as a cautionary tale not to exploit their god's blessings.

name: Brooch of the Cat
desc: Blessed by Alzheira Bethset, cleric of Sharess, on Midsummer's Eve 1373 DR, this brooch offers its wearer a small degree of protection from both physical harm and the dangers of cold weather and magic.  (In other words, it captures both the lucky grace and love of warmth characteristic of Sharess's favorite animal, the cat.)  Alzheira crafted it for herself before she arrived in the bitter lands north of the Moonsea, but soon discovered that it was possible to create a safe, warm place even there, and decided to sell it to merchants traveling west.

name: Brooch of Polished Coral
desc: This beautiful brooch of polished coral has been crafted in a strange but very attractive fashion. It is, in fact, a rare treasure--the brooch of a sea elven artisan from the Inner Sea. It is unusual for those who dwell on Faerun to come across such treasures, and its rareness is enhanced by its antiquity: this particular piece predates the advent of human civilization. Because it would certainly be recognizable by any reputable merchant in Drawn Swords as one of Asterchord's treasures, it's likely that only someone with less scrupulous buying habits would purchase it from you.

name: Craftsman's Elixir
desc: This odd brew was specially designed by clerics of Gond to aid the Melvauntian smiths on emergency commissions.  Upon ingestion, the elixir increases the drinker's capacity to strike true and hard with the hammer (or any other blunt instrument).  Dundeld Nanther forbade its continued manufacture after it turned a few bar brawls with clubs into lethal frays.

name: Costume Cyricist Armor
desc: enter item's description here

name: Costume Cyricist Armor (Cleric)
desc: enter item's description here

name: Cyricist Shield
desc: This shield is of Zhentarim craftsmanship, and is standard issue for many lower-rank caravan guards, soldiers, and priests in the service of the Black Network.  It is not magical.

name: Delhaller Gold Scale Armor
desc: This suit of gold scale armor is an heirloom of the Delhaller Clan, an old clan of shield dwarves from the cold land of Vaasa.  Delhalls, a deep iron and gem mine near the Ice Run Glacier, was their ancestral home.  When Goldroy Delhaller, brother to the clan chief, set out to search for mercenaries in the south to reclaim the place, he donned this suit of armor both in honor of his ancestors and for its powerful protective magic.  The suit is made of a magical alloy of gold and iron, a favorite medium of much late shield-dwarven craftsmanship.  His trip was unsuccessful, and he ended up spending the rest of his in Beregost, using the revenue from the sale of this armor to drown his sorrows.

name: Dire Hunter
desc: Reluvethel was a fierce opponent, and his bow rarely missed its mark and even more rarely failed to damage his quarry.  In the Siege of Dlabbradath, this bow felled no fewer than ninety-three soldiers of the Army of Darkness, many of them the arsons responsible for the destruction of the norteastern quadrant of Myth Drannor.  It is said by some that he felled three Nycaloths--elite, gargoyle-like demons--with one arrow sent from this bow.

name: Egdar's Screaming Greataxe
desc: A Northlander ruffian made quite a name for himself in the city of Luskan with this greataxe.  Egdar Eskith was a brute of a man, standing nearly seven feet tall, and often sought out quarrels on Luskan’s dirty streets, prowling about at all hours looking for people to intimidate out of their money.  A telltale scream echoed through the alleys often enough when he found prey.  A group of vigilantes eventually brought him down: sticking to the shadows, they used the sounds of the screaming axe to pinpoint Egdar’s location while he was fighting, and shot his body full of arrows.

name: Costume Elven Chain
desc: enter item's description here

name: Elverquisst
desc: Elverquisst is a wine unlike any other.  It is rumored to be a compound of sunlight, sweet fragrance, and the choicest grapes of the elven vineyards of Evermeet, and there is certainly some magic in its production.  While red wines often boast a ruby color, the ruby hue of this wine is so deep as to be almost opaque to any light softer than that of the sun.

name: Embramaph Extract
desc: Embramaph or "fairflower" is a common folk remedy for snake and spider poisons, and is also well-known for its irregular, rich purple flowers.  This careful distillation has enhanced its potency and its longevity.

name: Eternal Helm
desc: Despite its name, this chainmail helm was only recently created.  It was forged at the behest of Palas Goodman, a young paladin of Kelemvor who served the new (and much more benign) god of death as a member of the church's Eternal Order in Iriaebor.  He had commissioned it so that its enhancement would enable him to combat undead more effectively, and so he could inspire his allies with confidence on the field of battle; unfortunately, Palas was himself overconfident in his abilities--or perhaps those of his new helm--and he did not survive the first battle in which he wore it.

name: The Executioner of Asbravn
desc: This sickle was in Brother Anselm's family for many years.  While its chief purpose was to help in the harvest, its magical edge--a gift, according to family tradition--of Chauntea herself, gave the item a double life as a weapon.  It was employed by many of Anselm's forefathers in their work as both farmers and village defenders ("Riders in Red Cloaks"), and earned its name serving the latter function, when Anselm's great-grandfather took an orc's head off with one sweep of its blade.

name: Felsul Flower Oil
desc: The sweet odor of felsul flowers is a prized scent throughout Faerun.  The yellow and purple flowers are harvested in spring from a scrubby, small tree native to northern Faerun that grows in rocky, otherwise barren soil.

name: The First Spear
desc: This weapon may have been the first such created and used by human hands; it is certainly the oldest such weapon still in existence.  It was discovered in a quarry in 1155 DR by a factotum who revered Gond, and is believed to date from circa -12,000, when the first human tribes gathered in the troubled elven nation of Keltormir.  The name of the clan which held this weapon is lost to deepest time.  Only the spear itself remains: the brave men who wielded it, and the foes which it slew, are as irretrievable to knowledge as are the millennia that have passed since its creation.

name: Freusen's Falchion
desc: The ruthlessness of Zhentil Keep and its servants is famous throughout Faerun, but what is less often considered is how vital this ruthlessness is to Zhentil Keep's continued existence.  Unapologetic cruelty placates the city's evil god; it fills the city's coffers with gold; and its greatest economic consequence--the stranglehold on Moonsea commerce--brings weapons like this, forged by one of Melvaunt's most skilled arcane smiths, into the service of the city and its church.  This falchion was created only recently; Freusen Esk, field marshal of the Zhentarim forces of Darkhold, received it after he drove his old falchion through the bellies of two Harpers who had infiltrated the fortress, breaking the weapon's blade in the process.

name: Gossam's Suit of Green
desc: The Green Children, clerics who serve the halfling nature goddess Sheela Peryroyl, often prefer leather armor to metal armor.  To make up for the cost in protection, they often magically enhance such suits.  Gossam Thistlefall was awarded this suit when he left his temple--the Ladyhall, in Corm Orp--to seek adventure and knowledge in the Backlands.

name: Grevelyan's Sword
desc:
A legendary hero in those parts of the North where history is kept alive, Grevelyan was a great general of the Kingdom of Man, the alliance of humans, halflings, and gnomes that formed after the collapse of Phalorm in 614 DR, the Year of the Shattered Scepter.  He brought many victories to the humans of Delimbiyr Vale during his tenure, but his most remarkable feat was singlehandedly destroying a band of fifty orcs in the High Moor with this sword, after all of his men were destroyed.  Many whispered that he had given up a piece of his soul to his sword to avenge their deaths, and that the fire that emanates from the blade is his yet-unspent anger.

Grevelyan was killed (while he was unarmed) in a riot only a day before his monarch was murdered by a Sharran assassin.  The sword has seen many owners since then; most recently, it was part of a large plunder the Zhentarim made in the Far Hills.

name: Mace of Grimfast Mourde
desc: This weapon was given by the dark clergy of Zhentil Keep to Grimfast Mourde, a one-time paladin of Ilmater whose jealousy of his brother-in-arms drove him to convert to the worship of the Black Lord.  Grimfast became a blackguard, and slew his friend as they traveled from the Battle of Bones to Berdusk.  Weakened considerably by both his adventures and the battle with his old friend, he himself was killed a day later.  The mace was recovered by a merchant who sold it in Baldur's Gate for far less than it was worth.

name: Grish-Thurgish
desc: The business end of this grisly staff has been set with the skull of some humanoid long past racial recognition, and it is from this grisly totem that the power of this staff derives.  The magic of the goblins--more primitive than that of civilized wizards, more arcane than the divine blessings of clerics, and more divinely inspired than the powers of sorcerers-- has peculiar properties, not least of which is the ability of transforming the superstitious awe of fetishes into real might.  The staff's name, Grish-Thurgish, means simply "Staff of Thurgish," the weapon's former owner.

name: Halfling's Head
desc: The name of this otherwise wonderful brew is the source of many a bawdy joke in the Western Heartlands, where the stout is native.  Its name actually reflects two things--the heavy froth that tops the beer when poured, and the fact that the brewery is owned and run by halflings living in Corm Orp.

name: Indigo Hallowscap
desc: Gossam has used his botanical lore to refine the extra indigo hallowscap you gathered into a potent magical powder. Normally, indigo hallowscap can only affect one's perception of reality--sometimes to a dangerous degree--, but Gossam has sublimated the psychotropic element so that it physically manifests the psychic potential of the fungus without any harmful hallucinogenic side effects.

name: The Code of the Harpers
desc: The Code of the Harpers by Edward of the Verdant Wood Candlekeep, 1340 DR "All actions have consequences and must always be considered as having them." "All should be able to live and to pursue their own goals as they wish, so long as an individual's freedom does not compromise another's." "It is the spirit of law, rather than law itself, that should order cities; and never should any city take too much from the land." "Humility and self-sacrifice are more noble than pride and power. History teaches us this; therefore, preserve legend and song." "Above all, Balance in all things."

name: The Hideous Suit of Honoril Elthen
desc: Like many who do battle with demons, Honoril Elthen, a knight of Impiltur's Order of the Triad (precursor organization to the Knights of Imphras II), was a man equally brave and grim, honorable and taciturn: he had seen a demonic host devour two of his best friends in the Battle of Moaning Gorge (756 DR), and was plagued with nightmares ever after.  His suit, before of silver, took on a rusty color--stained, many said, by the blood of his slain compatriots, the demons, or both--and its powers, before meant to enhance Honoril's presence and carriage at court, likewise changed.

name: Hyra's Robe of Battle
desc: A wizard among dwarves, even if accepted (and even admired), will never garner as much respect as a warrior of equal power.  As a concession to this prejudice, many dwarven wizards make garments such as this, which offers a small degree of magical protection for those wishing to attempt the front line on occasion.  Hyra Delhaller, sister to Goldroy, wove this green robe from textiles purchased at the temporary trade city of Bildoobaris.  Like Goldroy's armor, it was sold to Oudin Asterchord to foot Goldroy's drinking bill in Beregost.

name: Kammarth Syrup
desc: Kammarth syrup is a thick, almost gelatinous compound of monkshood root extract and kammarth, a fungus that grows in the Underdark.  It can greatly increase its imbiber's speed.

name: Marune's Old Cape
desc: Marune the Masked, notorious necromancer of the Waterdhavian branch of the Shadow Thieves, made this cape decades ago; it served him well, but its powers eventually became less useful to him as his own powers increased and made the cape's minor protective magics seem trivial.  He sold it, along with his estate and some other magical trinkets, in 1342 DR, the Year of the Behir, to Torleth Mindulspeer, the famous collector.

name: Chain Shirt of Twilight's Falling
desc: One of the many works of elven military craftsmanship to have survived the Weeping War, this antique mithral chain shirt shines as brightly now as it did when Evithelathas, an earnest, grim-lipped young elf of the Akh'Velahr, wore it at the battle of Twilight's Falling (712 DR).  For many years it lay in the hands of the Harpers, until it finally made its way to Torleth Mindulspeer's shop, where it was purchased by Oudin Asterchord.  Its antiquity and legacy--not to mention its functionality--make it a valuable item indeed.

name: Mithral Bastard Sword (Masterwork)
desc: Despite the silvery, almost radiant mithral of its blade and its uncannily balanced poise when held, this bastard sword is not magical.  Its lightness, sharpness, and swiftness are unmatched, though, by any mundane weapon, and even by many magical weapons.

name: Monkshood
desc: Named after the poisonous plant, this unique item was the prize of Rapachin, a halfling monk and member of Luiren's Hin Fist.  He specialized in the cultivation of toxic plants and the refinement of botanical drugs for the purposes of his order and, knowing the occasionally insidious influence of the plants he loved, he had this hood made as a precaution against the most volatile of them.

name: Bikrash Studded Leather
desc: This suit of armor is of orcish craftsmanship, and bears a number of painted markings in the orcish tongue, indicating that it, like many suits of magical armor, is an heirloom.  This particular piece belonged to the Bikrash clan of the Sunset Mountains, and saw frequent battle with men from Iriaebor.

name: Corm Orp Mulled Cider
desc: This hard cider is spiced and fermented in Corm Orp, famous for its orchards, and then shipped north to Drawn Swords along the Sunset Trail.  It is served warm, but not so warm as to burn off any of the beverage's potent alcohol.

name: Cape of the Scarlet Mummers
desc: This bright garment was woven specifically for the elite assassins known as the "Scarlet Mummers," an order of Lliirans who put their grace and agility to use against the enemies of their goddess--specifically Loviatar, Maiden of Pain.  Unlike other assassins, the Mummers prize display and showmanship over stealth and secrecy, and their flamboyant technique is as beautiful to watch as it is deadly.

name: Battleaxe (Masterwork)
desc: This finely made battleaxe bears the mark of Hamfast Bairnson, the smith and leader of the hamlet known as Drawn Swords.  The mark shows two crossed swords superimposed on the silhouette of a keep.

name: Club (Masterwork)
desc: This surprisingly well-made club bears the mark of the Surefeet Trademasters, and was probably the property of an elite guard of that trading coster.

name: Dagger (Masterwork)
desc: This finely made dagger bears the mark of Hamfast Bairnson, the smith and leader of the hamlet known as Drawn Swords.  The mark shows two crossed swords superimposed on the silhouette of a keep.

name: Dwarven Waraxe (Masterwork)
desc: This dwarven waraxe is, as might be expected, of dwarven make.  Great care and precision usually characterize dwarven smithing, but this axe looks exceptionally well-balanced, though not magical.

name: Greataxe (Masterwork)
desc: This finely made greataxe bears the mark of Hamfast Bairnson, the smith and leader of the hamlet known as Drawn Swords.  The mark shows two crossed swords superimposed on the silhouette of a keep.

name: Gloves (Masterwork)
desc: These well-crafted deerskin gloves protect the hands of the martial artist, making forceful blows easier to execute.

name: Greatsword (Masterwork)
desc: This sharp, well-forged blade is forged in an outdated--but still quite effective--mold.  It is not magical, but its poise and balance make it an extremely effective piece of weaponry.

name: Halberd (Masterwork)
desc: This finely made halberd bears the mark of House Ulthveil, a Berduskan firm specializing in masterwork weapons.

name: Handaxe (Masterwork)
desc: This finely made handaxe bears the mark of Hamfast Bairnson, the smith and leader of the hamlet known as Drawn Swords.  The mark shows two crossed swords superimposed on the silhouette of a keep.

name: Heavy Crossbow (Masterwork)
desc: The copper fittings on this well-made crossbow indicate that it was manufactured in Arrowpoint, Highdale, the enclave of an elite group of archer mercenaries.

name: Katana (Masterwork)
desc: This exotic-looking sword bears an unfamiliar mark, but is almost certainly of Kara-Turan manufacture.  It is not magical but seems exceedingly sharp and light.

name: Kukri (Masterwork)
desc: Though the woodwork of its hilt is primitive, this kukri's blade looks particularly well-balanced and sharp.  It was probably forged by goblinoid hands, as goblins often prefer this wicked-looking weapon to a standard hunting knife.

name: Light Hammer (Masterwork)
desc: This finely made hammer bears the mark of Hamfast Bairnson, the smith and leader of the hamlet known as Drawn Swords. The mark shows two crossed swords superimposed on the silhouette of a keep; in addition, the initials "H.B." seem to indicate that this was the smith's property.

name: Longbow (Masterwork)
desc: Two back-to-back, stylized B's have been engraved in this exceedingly well-made longbow.  This is the mark of Bent Bows, a bowyer based in the town of Hill's Edge.

name: Longsword (Masterwork)
desc: This well-balanced longsword bears the mark of House Ulthveil, a Berduskan firm specializing in masterwork weapons.

name: Longsword (Masterwork)
desc: An unusually fine blade, forged in the hyrbid claymore style common among the smiths of the Moonshae Isles.

name: Light Crossbow (Masterwork)
desc: Two back-to-back, stylized B's have been engraved in this exceedingly light and sleek-looking crossbow.  This is the mark of Bent Bows, a bowyer based in the town of Hill's Edge.

name: Morningstar (Masterwork)
desc: This morningstar is light in the hand and exceedingly well-made.  It bears the mark of Matteo of Phlan, a man whose masterwork weapons were popular among elite militias thirty years ago.

name: Scimitar (Masterwork)
desc: The intricate ornamentation on this scimitar's blade indicate that it was probably made in Amn, where masterwork weapons such as this are often decorative as well as functional.

name: Shortbow (Masterwork)
desc: Two back-to-back, stylized B's have been engraved in this exceedingly well-made shortbow.  This is the mark of Bent Bows, a bowyer based in the town of Hill's Edge.

name: Spear (Masterwork)
desc: Gnolls are not known for their expert craftsmanship, but this fierce-looking spear of gnollish manufacture is light, long, and suited for swift killing.

name: Short Sword (Masterwork)
desc: This simple, cruel-looking short sword represents orcish craftsmanship at its finest.

name: Warmace (Masterwork)
desc: This warmace is heavy but more well-balanced than most weapons of this type.  It bears the unmistakable black fist of Bane, symbol of Zhentil Keep, on its head, and is obviously of Zhentarim craftsmanship.

name: Narwine
desc: Narwine is not wine at all, but an incredibly strong spirit made of various grains, and flavored with pungent herbs native to the plains of Narfell.  It is a notoriously abrasive and powerful liquor, and is a favorite among traders during the tenday Trade Fair in Bildoobaris.

name: Orc-Gnat
desc: This sling appears to be quite normal until it is brought within proximity of orcs, when it begins to make a sound not unlike the high-pitched wail of a gnat.  It tends to strike true against orcish foes, and also to provide minor protective magics against them--and unlike the common gnat, it adds a piercing bite to each successful volley its bullets make.  This unusual but effective weapon was the property of a gnomish warrior who fought side-by-side with the dwarves of Tempus's Tears--a little-known hamlet in the Fields of the Dead--against a small invasion of orcs in 1321 DR.  Time quickly forgets small heroes, and the sling passed into relative oblivion among the trade routes of the Sword Coast, whence it eventually fell into the hands of Oudin Asterchord.

name: Planesreaver
desc: Of the many dwarves who fell in the defense of Ammarindar when demons swept through the realm in the Year of the Curse (882 DR), the one who prevailed most often and whose arm smote the greatest number of the Abyssal host was Ierbish Handstone, a warpriest of Moradin.  His god had sent him a vision of the demonic invasion and inspired him to create this weapon, which Ierbish did in one long, painful night, hewing the iron without a fire and, when his hammer broke, pounding it into its present shape with a large stone.  Moradin blessed the effort and guided Ierbish's hand both in crafting and in battle--in vain, perhaps, given the doom of Ammarindar; but at least Ierbish's name and his last great craftwork, christened "Planesreaver," live on.

name: Rapier (Masterwork)
desc: The intricate ornamentation on this rapier's blade indicate that it was probably made in Amn, where masterwork weapons such as this are often decorative as well as functional.

name: Red Rune Shield
desc: This shield was won by Gedhardt Sonnlinor, of Clan Delhaller, in battle with a powerful barbarian warpriest of one of the numerous tribes of the Nars.  Gedhardt reconsecrated it to his god, Moradin, but it is otherwise unchanged.  Magical items such as this are relatively rare among the barbarians, the enchantment of them being a process much more difficult for untutored shamans than it is for genuine wizards, and Gedhardt was right to think of this shield as a curious prize.

name: Reluvethel's Chainmail
desc: Even the elves, who typically disdain human- and dwarf-forged armors and armor in favor of their own own elegant craftsmanship, were forced to use the implements of war of the N'Tel'Quessir in the Weeping War. This is one such suit. It was forged by a human on special commision from Reluvethel, the famous archer of Northdark Wood, who desired that it be made without arm protection on the right arm in order to facilitate pulling of the bowstring.

name: Ring of Ranger's Prayer
desc: Rangers especially favored by their god, as Reluvethel of Northdark was, sometimes wake (under the shadow of an old oak, or upon the dewy grass of a meadow; it always happens outside) to find that some mundane item in their possession has been enhanced with incredible magical powers.  Reluvethel was a fervent worshiper of Solonor Thelendira, as well-befitted a master of the longbow, and the god himself touched this plain silver ring that the ranger had worn since the days of his youth in Cormanthyr.

name: Ring of the Ghost
desc: This strange piece of jewelry was crafted by a little-known rogue of the Moonshaes named Perth Mwerde.  He remains little-known, not because he was unsuccessful, but because he lived a life of secrecy and isolation, creating trinkets that would help him get riches, which in turn helped him create more trinkets--his life's one small passion.  Perth theorized that by modifying a certain necromantic enfeebling spell, he might be able to distill some benefit from the incantation's vitality-sapping essence into a ring.  This ring would make the wearer more ghost-like when circumstance required it, but would draw on his physical strength while worn.  This is the product of his labor.

name: Ring of Merry Revels
desc: One of a set of three identical rings crafted during the Time of Troubles, this gold ring is set with garnet and topaz in a stylized representation of Lliira's triangular holy symbol.  The set was commissioned by Selgaunt's Lliiran church for its three top priestesses after the High Revelmistress, Chlanna Asjros, was slain by Loviatari agents.  The rings' minor protective magics were not enough for them, though, and they commissioned a more powerful set, selling this one to merchants heading to Scornubel.

name: Sashenstar's Talisman
desc: This protective talisman was once owned by none other than Dabron Sashenstar: Dabron, the famous explorer who discovered Sossal in the Year of the Prince; the man, presumed dead, who vanished for years in the Endless Wastes and was adopted by the Tuigan barbarians; the very same who even now leads the Merchant's League as one of Faerun's greatest merchant princes.  He wore it close to his breast during his days in the Wastes, and its power made him slightly less vulnerable to the perils he encountered there.  When he returned to Baldur's Gate, he gladly sold the necklace and purchased a better; not all of the memories he associated with the piece of jewelry were fond ones.

name: Shielding Ring of Wizardry
desc: Though the scrupulous collector Oudin Asterchord does not usually do business with Thayans, he could not pass up this unusual item.  Forged before the Red Wizards had become the dominant force in the trade of magical commodities in Faerun, the enchantment upon it was experimental; if it could be successfully reproduced, the Red Wizards imagined, it would certainly be an attractive item to wizards from the Moonsea to the Sea of Swords.  Though the enchantment itself did prove to be incredibly useful, the process by which the ring was enchanted was far too time-consuming and tedious to enable the Red Wizards to efficiently create more.  They abandoned it after too much gold was wasted on the attempt.  Meanwhile, the young abjurer who had insisted that the process could be refined was, of course, killed for his ineptitude.

name: Bracers of the Smith
desc: Brenor Highcastle was a smith who was also a lifelong priest of Gond.  A maker of extraordinary suits of armor himself, Brenor was somewhat picky where armor was concerned, and could not tolerate the feel of a roughly crafted suit, especially when working at the forge.  Being without armor in the wilds of Vaasa, however, was not an option.  Instead of creating a suit of armor that would meet his exacting standards--a process which could take months and a great amount of gold--he forged and enchanted these bracers, which have a peculiar way of enhancing one's natural grace.  Brenor eventually left Vaasa and retired to Waterdeep, where Torleth Mindulspeer, the collector, purchased these bracers from him.

name: Tempuran Shield
desc: This battered shield of darkly stained wood, set in the margins with gleaming bloodstones, was consecrated to Tempus in 1347 DR, Year of the Bright Blade, when the Tethyrian civil war began.  After the eager young warpriest to whom it had belonged lost a limb in a battle with the Pretender's forces, he joined the Tempuran Order of the Broken Blade and donated his old shield to the church.  The collector Torleth Mindulspeer purchased it on a trip through Tethyr.

name: Tenley Red Wine
desc: This is a relatively cheap wine from Sembia, where the prosperous Tenleys make a fortune off their wine monopoly.  It is bold and a little tannic.

name: Thousandheads Flail
desc: This flail was forged on behalf of Emnol Tarthisel, chief guard of the Thousandheads Trading Coster, an outfit that ensures and protects caravans traveling the route from Waterdeep to Hillsfar.  Emnol was known for his vigilance and canniness on the road, and wise merchants paid extra to have their goods conveyed by his team.  Unfortunately, his wisdom did not hold when he was in town.  After drinking heavily one night in Scornubel, City of Caravans, Emnol was murdered by a young priest of Bane named Obern Severn, and his flail taken as a prize.

name: Thrallwine
desc: Also called jhuild for one of its primary ingredients, this wine-colored brew is made in Thesk from a fermentation of herbal extracts and fruit juice.  It can greatly enhance the strength of its imbiber with no side effects, as the skill of the alchemist who made it has removed its mind-numbing toxins.

name: Gloves of the Trapmaster
desc: Amber "the Trapmaster" Roguestone-Stone has a trap-finding, -disarming, and -evading career as storied as her name is unwieldy.  Her last feat was the successful dismantling of the famous and deadly Kara-Turan Trap of One Thousand and One Needles (each needle of which, it is said, is coated with a different deadly poison, making antidotes and single-application spells useless).  After disabling this, Amber found it impossible to find another suitable challenge and retired to Lantan, becoming full professor of Perilous Security Technology at the University of Gond.  Students majoring in P.S.T. whisper rumors of these magical gloves, without which, they say, it would have been impossible for Professor Roguestone-Stone to disarm the Kara-Turan trap.  This is likely true, and the very reason that Amber had the wits to sell the evidence on the continent before she sailed to Lantan.

name: Tybalt's Black Sun Armor
desc: Forged in secret by the Cyricist faction of the Darkhold Zhentarim, this suit of blackened banded mail was the treasure of Tybalt Egarde, a ruthless and energetic servant of Cyric and would-be rival to the leader of Darkold's Cyricists, the man known as the Pereghost.  Before the Zhentarim were driven from Darkhold, when the in-fighting between the Cyricists and Banites was at its height, Tybalt had the suit consecrated to his dark god by washing it in the blood of five of his Banite enemies (and one of his Cyricist ones).

name: Varathar Powder
desc: This dark, musty powder is made of the stems and leaves of varathar, a groundcover native to northern Faerun.  It has minor magical healing properties and is somewhat rare outside the forests of the Silver Marches.

name: Vhardris's Padded Suit
desc: This suit of padded armor was worn by the rogue Vhardris Dreirkuth, a drow who had ridden the tides of the mordayn and bloodfast drug trades to the north.  Born and raised in the dismal Underdark city of Llurth Dreir, far to the south, Vhardris was little more than an urchin before he realized the potential of trafficking with surfacers in the volatile compounds common enough in the slums of the Accursed City.  This suit was one of the first items he bought with his revenue, and it accompanied him on many a sale.  It is light in weight and dark in color, and offers minor protective magic to its wearer, along with the modicum of protection afforded by padded armor.

name: Wagner's Ritual Gloves
desc: Before the forces of Zhentil Keep conquered Mintar, a monk and demonological scholar by the name of Wagner unwisely summoned a demon to protect his monastery.  It was the first such being Wagner had ever beheld; to his great fortune, the heart attack he suffered upon viewing that which he had long studied killed him before the demon could.  But demons are nothing if not gratuitous, and the beast still tore his corpse apart, leaving behind only these special ritual gloves (which it disdained to touch).

name: Warhammer (Masterwork)
desc: The unusual floral filigree on this warhammer suggests that it was gnomish handiwork.  It is incredibly light in the hands, especially for such a typically heavy weapon.

name: Wundertraf
desc: This ceremonial-looking warhammer was designed and forged by clerics of Gond in honor of their god's own weapon, Craftmaster.  For many years it occupied the House of Gond in Tilverton, but when that city was destroyed by the Shadovar in 1372 DR, the Year of Wild Magic, the hammer found its way west in the hands of an adventurer--one who had the courtesy to donate it to the temple of Gond in Baldur's Gate.

name: Costume Zhent Armor
desc: enter item's description here

name: Costume Zhent Armor (Priest)
desc: enter item's description here

name: Costume Zhent Armor (Scout)
desc: enter item's description here

name: Zhentarim Shield
desc: This shield is of Zhentarim craftsmanship, and is standard issue for many lower-rank caravan guards, soldiers, and priests in the service of the Black Network.  It is not magical.

name: Farmer Zhi's Kama
desc: The kama, or "hand scythe" as it is sometimes known outside of Kara-Tur, was originally a farming instrument.  This particular kama has clearly outlived its humble origins, though it reminds its viewer of them with a number of inlaid representations of rustic life upon its blade.  It belonged to a wealthy farmer in distant Tu' Lung whose family, it was discovered, had connections to that of the T'u Emperor.  When the forces of Shou Lung burned and salted the farmer's extensive holdings, his fortunes were reversed once more, and he sold the magcal weapon to merchants traveling the Golden Way to Faerun.

name: The Scalpel of Armaithez
desc: Beaten out of cold iron to a wicked point, this blade belonged to none other than Armaithez al-Exhar, the Calishite goetic scholar who, driven mad by his long hours of study and occasional Abyssal visitations, sought the fabled Black Spire of Demons among the Calim Desert's white sands.  He set out alone, naked except for this dagger.  While it is true that its power against demons was great, and had served Armaithez well on many occasions--including in his own investigations of the glabrezu's inner anatomy--it could not save him from the sandstorm that took his life.

name: Barrow Key
desc: You found this key on a mummy in a barrow in the Backlands.  It opens the doors that lead into the tomb.

name: Robe of the Apprentice
desc: Robes like this are the pride of nobles who study magic at one of Waterdeep's arcane academies.  This one was crafted on behalf of a young mage of House Amcathra who trained at Eltorchul Academy.  After acquiring the robe, Hanlon Amcathra attempted to transfer to the more prestigious Blackstaff Tower; he was not, however, accepted.  Eventually deciding against academic magic altogether in favor of ever more esoteric pursuits, Hanlon donated his old robe to the Library House of the Black Cult of Ahm when he became a Seeker Initiate of that order.

name: Belt of Exalted Strength
desc: This belt belonged to Galauntar Hawkhelm, commander of the Citadel Raven when allies of the Zhentarim struck there in the Year of the Harp (1355 DR).  Galauntar was killed in the battle, but the belt was passed on, eventually becoming legendary among the Knights of the North, the small Moonsea order of fighters and vigilantes who formed specfically to fight the Zhentarim after the attack.  Despite great reservations, a representative of the Knights recently sold it to Oudin in order to finance and outfit new recruits to their cause.

name: none
desc: enter item's description here

name: An Old Ring of Protection
desc: The history of this ring is overwhelmingly various, having passed through the hands of numerous adventurers since its creation long ago.  Most recently, it was recovered from a tree stump where it had inexplicably been secreted, and saw many adventures along the Sword Coast, until an ambush on its owner, and a circuitous path of circumstances, brought it into Northdark Wood--where, once again, it inexplicably lay in an odd place, among the yellow grasses of a marshy clearing.

name: Amaunatori Ring
desc: The history of this ring is overwhelmingly various, having passed through the hands of numerous adventurers since its creation long ago.  Most recently, it was recovered from a tree stump where it had inexplicably been secreted, and saw many adventures along the Sword Coast, until an ambush on its owner, and a circuitous path of circumstances, brought it into Northdark Wood--where, once again, it inexplicably lay in an odd place, among the yellow grasses of a marshy clearing.

name: Maker's Mark
desc: This dagger was forged in Llorkh, the notorious Zhent trading post on the Black Road, by the head of a local guild of thieves, Iermvin Losston, a little too prone to the bottle.  When one's best pickings are sinister priests of Bane, unscrupulous merchants, and wanderers brave enough to adventure in the Savage Frontier, one does not last long, especially if one drinks excessively--and so, unfortunately, it was for Iermvin.  The dagger made its way to the Sword Coast in the hands of orcish marauders in league with the Zhents, until it was lost in a skirmish with an indigenous tribe.

name: Falcon's Loss
desc: This sword belonged to the robber-knight known as Ludos, the same man, as it turns out, who was responsible for the anonymous ballad "The Falcon and the Dove."  It was with this very sword that he cleared the plot of land in the Backlands where Castle Joyous would stand, his home until the love between him and the song dragon he called "the Dove" came to an end when he discovered her true nature.  The sword was buried with Ludos's corpse by his confessor, a trusted priestess of Helm who sealed his body away from prying eyes with the door's magical inscription; little did Ludos know that this priestess was none other than his old beloved, who had assumed that shape so that she could be with him in his final hours.  The sorrow that kept them apart in life did not stop with his death, and the sword you now hold bears traces of that old sadness.

name: Obern's Key
desc: You found this key on the body of Obern, the treacherous Banite who had pretended to be an acolyte of Ilmater.

name: Obern's Letter Fragment
desc: This scrap of paper, found at the bottom of the trunk in Obern and Dunne's quarters, appears to have been part of a letter, the rest of which was probably destroyed (along with anything else of informational value in the trunk). What survives reads: Do not leave Drawn Swords until his arrival. There is no signature, but the hand of the letter is firm and precise.

name: Obern's Starched Tunic
desc: This appears to be nothing more than a starched tunic in the drab, severe style of an acolyte of Ilmater.  However, a very subtle enchantment has been placed on it by its former owner, the dark priest and spy Obern Severn, giving it slight protective benefits.  Even a modicum of protection can mean the difference between life and death in such a line of work, though this was not enough for Obern in the end.

name: Hamfast's Skeleton Key
desc: Hamfast gave you this key so that you could open up the door of Brother Anselm's house.

name: A Treatise Toward Unity
desc:
A TREATISE TOWARD UNITY:
Comparisons of the People and Humanity in Art and Life
by Arun Maerdrymm of Myth Drannor (503 DR)

...in this fastidiousness of detail, for instance, we elves are rarely surpassed by any other race; but in men, so great is their aptitude for intense and prolonged exertion, that they can produce works of equal intricacy in much shorter periods of time than the People would ever dare; not because it is beyond us, but because our very natures prohibit us from vocations where grace is pursued, not granted....

So, it is said, in the first civilizations of men, and indeed still among some of their barbarians, that they resemble and act like the hated goblinoid peoples; but this infancy has, for the majority of them, passed, and as their civilization grows greater it acquires the love of temperance, egalitarianism, and beauty that elven society has always promoted....

And in unison, therefore, let us proclaim Myth Drannor the proudest of Faerun's cities, the glory of two races, and the envy of others; our peace everlasting, our foes vanquished, our mutual sympathy and respect forever fruitful....

name: Ace of Coins
desc: This unusual item has no obvious magical aura or properties.  But according to legend, It was the combination of keen wit and keener luck--brought to him by this coin--that allowed the notorious Waterdhavian gambler Ardorus Laughten his five years' run of fortune; it was because of this coin that the brash young nobleman Pierlin Forsweith was confident enough to risk his life on a game of dice--ten times in a row--and live;  it was this coin that was eagerly sought by clerics of Tymora for almost certainly being an artifact of the goddess of luck's power.  The luck, however, seems only to apply to games of chance.  The extra edge it always gives its possessors at cards or dice is not the kind with which one can defend oneself--and as it turned out, many of the coin's possessors provoked the ire of their disappointed opponents.

name: Elven Sapphire Necklace
desc: This is a fine necklace of silver, and its pendant is a stylized representation of Angharradh's holy symbol, set with three tiny sapphires--one, presumably, for each of the aspects of the Triune Goddess.

name: Boots of the Unicorn
desc: These boots once belonged to a gnome priestess of Mielikki named Isabel Fenbeedle.  Like all servants of Mielikki, Isabel loved the out-of-doors and all things wild and natural; but above all else, she adored and venerated the unicorn, her goddess's holy symbol.  Now, Isabel had grown powerful over the years, and when her offices denied the Zhentarim from trading with her community, the Zhents sought to have her killed.  A Zhentarim spy in her town began spreading rumors of a unicorn that would visit the local apple orchard in the early morning hours.  Isabel heard the rumors and, expecting to witness the beautiful creature first-hand, took herself to the orchard in her favorite boots one morning--where she was immediately cut down by a group of laughing Zhentarim, and robbed of her possessions.  No sooner had Isabel fallen, though, then a true unicorn appeared in the orchard.  All who looked on the beast perished, but a canny young Zhent named Freusen snatched Isabel's old boots and fled.

name: Vroman's Hat
desc: According to Vroman, a finely made hat is key to cutting a dashing figure.  This hat is less ostentatious than some of the feathered, wide-brim numbers popular along the Sword Coast, but it is no less finely made. Vroman considers the hat blessed by Tymora--and indeed, there is more than a hint of magic about it.

name: Treatise on Good Wifery
desc:
TREATISE ON GOOD WIFERY
By Miriam Buttercake of Ashabenford (1298 DR)
Dalelands Men's Society Reprints (1358 DR)

Good wifery begins with being a good wife.  A good wife keeps herself fit, clean, and docile, her hair of moderate length, and purchases clothing that is neither plain nor rich, as a husband's resources are finite, and clothing too obvious an extravagance to maintain.  Spare time does not exist for a good wife, but in those moments when she finds herself less busy, she might cultivate the sciences of cookery, flattery, and Sune....

When a good wife finds herself in conflict with her husband, she must always be the reed that bends, and not the tree that snaps; in yielding there is always great pleasure for a good wife, and there is likewise in men a great tendency to blow....

When a good wife finds herself in the unfortunate position of having lost her husband, she must go through a long period of mourning.  This period should last as long as her love for her husband lasted, which is usually a period of some months.  She is advised to continue to act the part of the good wife throughout, and when finally relieved of the burden of mourning, to live a happy, long widowhood, without stratagem, subtlety, or deceit--in other words, the very same kind of life she is used to.

name: Zhentarim Military Portfolio
desc:
This portfolio of plans contains maps, strategic reports, and the locations of various Zhentarim scouting parties from the Backlands to Sunset Vale.  Without knowing the context, much of the data is useless.  You can, however, glean the following facts:

1.  The Zhentarim encampment you found is one of many.

2.  The Zhentarim forces seem to be scouting the area.

3.  The forces are remarkably scattered and poorly organized.

4.  Drawn Swords does not appear as a target on any of the maps or plans.

5.  Darkhold, the well-known fortress of the Zhentarim in the Sunset Mountains, has been taken by an unnamed force.
